p: Gaudrealt et al. [45]. provide a comprehensive review of reassortment of RVFV, citing examples from experimental and field studies with LAVs. The review supports the conclusion that, while reassortant wild-type viruses have been identified, this was an uncommon phenomenon. The evidence provided for reassortment between wild-type and attenuated LAVs in natural infection was limited to the SA184/10 strain from the patient with a needle stick injury cited earlier, for which full genomic sequencing indicates that it is not a reassortant virus [2]. Where reassortment has been demonstrated in experimental studies (by coinfection in vitro or in mosquitoes) no evidence for strains of increased pathogenicity has been found.
